update.description:
This builds on top of ~~pull request #129~~ **merged**

---

This is an alternative to pull request #127 which has both `components::ParentEntity` and a graph within the ECM storing the parent-child relationship between entities. Since keeping these in sync is prone to errors, we provide convenient functions in `gazebo::Factory` which do the correct thing so the end user doesn't need to worry about it.
update.title: [A-6] Entity graph + factory

content.raw: @nkoenig , I'll merge this now, but as we spoke yesterday, let's revisit the API classes and the ECM's ownership for Ign-B.
content.html: @nkoenig , I'll merge this now, but as we spoke yesterday, let's revisit the API classes and the ECM's ownership for Ign-B.

content.raw: Sorry, I probably should have added more context to the PR. I'm using this in the [UserCommands system](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/241fb13dd0168e71de3ddc735747f462e5674312/src/systems/usercommands/UserCommands.cc?at=user_cmds&fileviewer=file-view-default#UserCommands.cc-48)
content.html: Sorry, I probably should have added more context to the PR. I'm using this in the UserCommands system

content.raw: Thanks for the info. That all makes sense, but I'm still left wondering why `Factory` exists. For example, I was able to remove it in pull request #142.
content.html: Thanks for the info. That all makes sense, but I'm still left wondering why Factory exists. For example, I was able to remove it in pull request #142.

content.raw:
Classes like `Factory` and `Model` were created to give plugin developers more intuitive interfaces than interacting with entities and components directly.

Some of the earlier commits in pull request #98 (the design doc) described the rationale in more detail, going from a pure ECM approach to the final interfaces, but as the pull request evolved I ended up removing important points. I'll make a new PR adding that back, but hopefully the document's [current state](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/3c4cb4f48bbfa61e8e3ed0acc1868a005e663671/doc/architecture_design.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#markdown-header-plugin-interfaces) gives you a bit more context for now.

So, to address your points:

1. It's meant to be installed and used by systems
1. The functionality could be added directly to the ECM, but then the ECM wouldn't be component-agnostic any more and no longer would have the single responsibility of managing arbitrary entities and components. Keeping the interfaces in separate classes gives users what they need when they need it. I'd like to encourage downstream developers to also create such interfaces for their custom components.
1. Perhaps the `Factory` name is misleading? Do you think it would make sense to keep spawn/delete functionality in the same class, but maybe give it a different name? This could also make it clearer for users who assume `Factory` has the classical meaning of creating objects, as you assumed.
content.html:
Classes like Factory and Model were created to give plugin developers more intuitive interfaces than interacting with entities and components directly.

Some of the earlier commits in pull request #98 (the design doc) described the rationale in more detail, going from a pure ECM approach to the final interfaces, but as the pull request evolved I ended up removing important points. I'll make a new PR adding that back, but hopefully the document's current state gives you a bit more context for now.

So, to address your points:

  1. It's meant to be installed and used by systems
  2. The functionality could be added directly to the ECM, but then the ECM wouldn't be component-agnostic any more and no longer would have the single responsibility of managing arbitrary entities and components. Keeping the interfaces in separate classes gives users what they need when they need it. I'd like to encourage downstream developers to also create such interfaces for their custom components.
  3. Perhaps the Factory name is misleading? Do you think it would make sense to keep spawn/delete functionality in the same class, but maybe give it a different name? This could also make it clearer for users who assume Factory has the classical meaning of creating objects, as you assumed.

content.raw:
I have some architectural suggestions:

1. Move `Factory.hh` to the `src` directory. It doesn't need to be installed.
2. Make the Factory a member of EntityComponentManager. 
3. Don't have the Factory erase elements, it's a bit counter intuitive. I'd also remove the `SetParent` functionality from the Factory. Basically, try to make the Factory just about creation.

It's also strange to have a Factory that calls create functions on the ECM. A factory usually consumes some data and returns a unique pointer (for example) to a newly created object. The current implementation is confusing, and I'm not sure why the Factory exists.

It would be nice to eliminate the double set of interfaces, one in EntitytComonentManger and one in the Factory.
content.html:
I have some architectural suggestions:

  1. Move Factory.hh to the src directory. It doesn't need to be installed.
  2. Make the Factory a member of EntityComponentManager.
  3. Don't have the Factory erase elements, it's a bit counter intuitive. I'd also remove the SetParent functionality from the Factory. Basically, try to make the Factory just about creation.

It's also strange to have a Factory that calls create functions on the ECM. A factory usually consumes some data and returns a unique pointer (for example) to a newly created object. The current implementation is confusing, and I'm not sure why the Factory exists.

It would be nice to eliminate the double set of interfaces, one in EntitytComonentManger and one in the Factory.

content.raw: Right now we're only supporting a single parent. I have some TODOs in the code asking if we want to support more in the future because I wasn't sure. The code is currently following the SDF hierarchy, which is a tree, i.e. joints and links are children of models.
content.html: Right now we're only supporting a single parent. I have some TODOs in the code asking if we want to support more in the future because I wasn't sure. The code is currently following the SDF hierarchy, which is a tree, i.e. joints and links are children of models.

content.raw: Change to `Set the parent of an entity`?
content.html: Change to Set the parent of an entity?

content.raw: I was trying to make it as large as possible, and using signed int just to use `-1` feels like a waste of half the range. But I'll revert the change in any case.
content.html: I was trying to make it as large as possible, and using signed int just to use -1 feels like a waste of half the range. But I'll revert the change in any case.

content.raw: Do you mean to say: `Get the first parent of the given entity`?
content.html: Do you mean to say: Get the first parent of the given entity?

content.raw: Can we still use `int`, maybe `int64t`? An int64 has a max value of 9,223,372,036,854,775,807 which is probably big enough. It will also let us use -1 as the Null case. I'm recommending this also because `std::numeric_limits<uint64_t>::max()` feels weird as a Null value.
content.html: Can we still use int, maybe int64t? An int64 has a max value of 9,223,372,036,854,775,807 which is probably big enough. It will also let us use -1 as the Null case. I'm recommending this also because std::numeric_limits<uint64_t>::max() feels weird as a Null value.

content.raw:
I'll add a `Factory::RequestEraseEntity` function soon. That will be the 4th class to have this function - we really need to revisit the role of `Server`, `SimulationRunner` and the `EntityComponentManager` at some point, because there isn't a clear separation of concerns between them.

First will make a separate PR implementing a convenient `EntityComponentManager::RemoveComponent`.

Putting this PR on hold.
content.html:
I'll add a Factory::RequestEraseEntity function soon. That will be the 4th class to have this function - we really need to revisit the role of Server, SimulationRunner and the EntityComponentManager at some point, because there isn't a clear separation of concerns between them.

First will make a separate PR implementing a convenient EntityComponentManager::RemoveComponent.

Putting this PR on hold.

content.raw: Nice catch. I think we can either not support non-recursive erasure for now, or provide an erasure interface that does the right thing through `Factory`.
content.html: Nice catch. I think we can either not support non-recursive erasure for now, or provide an erasure interface that does the right thing through Factory.

content.raw: Since we're supporting non-recursive entity erasure, this could be a potential place for the graph and the `ParentEntity` component to go out of sync. If we remove an entity that is a parent to a number of child entities, the parent-child relationship is automatically removed from the graph, but we still have to remove the `ParentEntity` component from each child entity.
content.html: Since we're supporting non-recursive entity erasure, this could be a potential place for the graph and the ParentEntity component to go out of sync. If we remove an entity that is a parent to a number of child entities, the parent-child relationship is automatically removed from the graph, but we still have to remove the ParentEntity component from each child entity.

content.raw: Yeah, I wanted to keep the `EntityComponentManager` component-agnostic. I'll add a function to `Factory`.
content.html: Yeah, I wanted to keep the EntityComponentManager component-agnostic. I'll add a function to Factory.

content.raw: I noticed that this doesn't create a `ParentEntity` component on the `_child` entity. It would be nice if there was a function that sets the parent in the graph and also creates the `ParentEntity` component on the child. Maybe it could go in the `Factory` class.
content.html: I noticed that this doesn't create a ParentEntity component on the _child entity. It would be nice if there was a function that sets the parent in the graph and also creates the ParentEntity component on the child. Maybe it could go in the Factory class.

content.raw:
Yeah I like that. I think it would also be nice to have a recursive option, like Qt's [findChild(ren)](http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qobject.html#findChild). I'll do at least the change you proposed.

Also worth mentioning that since we're not getting rid of `ParentEntity` anymore, this function isn't strictly necessary right now.
content.html:
Yeah I like that. I think it would also be nice to have a recursive option, like Qt's findChild(ren). I'll do at least the change you proposed.

Also worth mentioning that since we're not getting rid of ParentEntity anymore, this function isn't strictly necessary right now.

content.raw: Oh gosh I was looking for a function that did that for a while, thanks, will change!
content.html: Oh gosh I was looking for a function that did that for a while, thanks, will change!

content.raw: It might be more efficient to call `entities.VertexFromId` and check if it returns `NullVertex`
content.html: It might be more efficient to call entities.VertexFromId and check if it returns NullVertex

content.raw: What do you think about making this `ChildrenByComponent` and return all entities that match? I think it could be useful, for example, to get all the links of a model.
content.html: What do you think about making this ChildrenByComponent and return all entities that match? I think it could be useful, for example, to get all the links of a model.

content.html:
I added another big-ish change to this PR. Now instead of reusing entities, they will be unique. I did this because when entities are deleted and inserted repeatedly very fast, possibly in the same iteration, it becomes difficult for systems to keep track of whether an entity is the same old one, or if it's a new one reusing that ID. That happens for example when levels are being loaded and unloaded.

I changed the entity type from int to uint64_t, so hopefully it will be difficult for simulations to reach that number. I suggest we revisit this in the future if the limit becomes an issue. If that ever happens, I'd suggest using up the whole range of possible entities before going back to the lower numbers - that will hopefully minimize the chance that the old and new entities overlap.

@nkoenig, I believe you were the one who originally implemented the entity reuse. Do you see any problem with this? All the adjacent memory tests are still passing.
